Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Cloud Computing Infrastructure for Research and Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal #: 13-38102
PI(s): Yu, Shucheng
Chiang, Chia-Chu; Xie, Mengjun; Yoshigoe, Kenji
Institution: University of Arkansas-Little Rock
Title: MRI/Acq.: Cloud Computing Infrastructure for Research and Education
Project Proposed:
This project, acquiring private cloud instrumentation, aims to conduct six research projects spanning areas of social networks, secure cloud data system, cryptography, biomedical computing, and data stream analysis. The instrumentation will enable the following projects:
- Analysis of Sybil Attacks in Large-Scale Social Networks,
- Secure Data Access Control for Cloud Storage Systems,
- Study of Cache Pollution Attacks in Named-Data Networking,
- Development of a Cloud-Based Graph Theoretical Analysis Framework for Human Brain Connectomes,
- Parallel Processing of Fully Homomorphic Encryption, and
- Performance Real-Time Stream Analysis on the Cloud.
This private cloud, serving three universities (U AR-Little Rock (UALR), U AR-Pine Bluff (UAPB), and
U Central AR (UAC)), will be the first in the state dedicated to research and teaching.
Broader Impacts:
The instrumentation enriches the research and educational activities within the universities and overall state. Hence, new courses can be developed and implemented. Moreover, the cloud infrastructure provides unique opportunities for minority students that will then have access to cutting-edge high-performance ubiquitous computing resources. The computing infrastructure creates many education and training opportunities for the students through the process of its installation, operation, and maintenance. A Summer Undergraduate Program of Entrepreneurship and Research (SUPER) program and the ACM club at the university will offer training within and beyond the institution. Also, an undergraduate summer research program on cloud computing will be established to expand the opportunities throughout this EPSCoR jurisdiction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project builds the first cloud instrument dedicated for research and education in the state of Arkansas. The acquired private cloud instrument has been utilized to primarily support six research projects: 1) analysis of Sybil attacks in large-scale social networks; 2) secure data access control for cloud storage systems; 3) study on cache pollution attacks in named-data networking; 4) development of a cloud-based graph theoretical analysis framework for human brain connectomes; 50 parallel processing of fully homomorphic encryption; and 6) performance real-time stream analysis on cloud. These projects has resulted in twelve research papers published in academic journals and conferences and two under submission. Three graduate students participated in the installation and daily maintenance of the cloud instrument and gained hands-on experiences. The cloud instrument has served as the research platform for over twenty undergraduate students across the nation through the NSF REU program at the University of Arkansas at Little Rock (UA Little Rock) and the summer undergraduate research program at UA Little Rock. The cloud has provided computing services to four courses at UA Little Rock. Both students and faculty were trained for cloud system during the knowledge transfer session offered by the vendor of this instrument. The cloud has supported two open-source cloud-based cybersecurity education and research software – Platoon and EZSetup – which has been shared and downloaded by 18 institutions and professionals from 6 countries.
